metadata.title: Constrained Graph Variational Autoencoders for Molecule Design
metadata.author: Qi Liu, Miltiadis Allamanis, Marc Brockschmidt, Alexander Gaunt
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: Graphs are ubiquitous data structures for representing interactions between entities. With an emphasis on applications in chemistry, we explore the task of learning to generate graphs that conform to a distribution observed in training data. We propose a variational autoencoder model in which both encoder and decoder are graphstructured. Our decoder assumes a sequential ordering of graph extension steps and we discuss and analyze design choices that mitigate the potential downsides of this linearization. Experiments compare our approach with a wide range of baselines on the molecule generation task and show that our method is successful at matching the statistics of the original dataset on semantically important metrics. Furthermore, we show that by using appropriate shaping of the latent space, our model allows us to design molecules that are (locally) optimal in desired properties.

highlights: Structured objects such as program source code, physical systems, chemical molecules and even 3D scenes are often well represented using graphs [2, 6, 16, 25]
We propose a novel probabilistic model for graph generation that builds gated graph neural networks (GGNNs) [21] into the encoder and decoder of a variational autoencoder (VAE) [15]

The encoder of our variational autoencoder is a gated graph neural networks Genc that embeds each node in an input graph G to a diagonal normal distribution in d-dimensional latent space parametrized by mean μv and standard deviation σv vectors
The results in Fig. 3 show that constrained graph variational autoencoder is excellent at matching graph statistics, while generating valid, novel and unique molecules for all datasets considered
We proposed constrained graph variational autoencoder, a sequential generative model for graphs built from a variational autoencoder with gated graph neural networks in the encoder and decoder
Future work will need to link to the chemistry community to define additional metrics that further guide the construction of models and datasets for real-world molecule design tasks

The encoder of our variational autoencoder is a gated graph neural networks Genc that embeds each node in an input graph G to a diagonal normal distribution in d-dimensional latent space parametrized by mean μv and standard deviation σv vectors
The results in Fig. 3 show that constrained graph variational autoencoder is excellent at matching graph statistics, while generating valid, novel and unique molecules for all datasets considered
As discussed in Sect. 4.3, we extend our architecture to predict the Quantitative Estimate of Drug-Likeness (QED) directly from latent space
We proposed constrained graph variational autoencoder, a sequential generative model for graphs built from a variational autoencoder with gated graph neural networks in the encoder and decoder

summary: Structured objects such as program source code, physical systems, chemical molecules and even 3D scenes are often well represented using graphs [2, 6, 16, 25].

Our approach uses the ingredients from Johnson [14], but avoids the training and overfitting problems using a model that is conditioned only on the current partial graph rather than on full generation traces.

This provides the model with both local information for the focus node v and the candidate edge, hu(t)), and global information regarding the original graph specification (Hinit) and the current graph state (H(t)).
New edges are sampled from these distributions, and any nodes that are connected to the graph for the first time are added to the focus queue.

The encoder of our VAE is a GGNN Genc that embeds each node in an input graph G to a diagonal normal distribution in d-dimensional latent space parametrized by mean μv and standard deviation σv vectors.

Given the initial collection of unconnected nodes, G(0), from the initialization above, we first use Jensen’s inequality to show that the log-likelihood of a graph G is loosely lower bounded by the expected log-likelihood of all the traces Π that generate it.
We can decompose each full generation trace π ∈ Π into a sequence of steps of the form (t, v, ), where v is the current focus node and = v ↔ u is the edge added at step t: log p(π | G(0)) =
We consider the set of generation states S of all valid state pairs s = (G(t), v) of a partial graph G(t) and a focus node v.
| could be generated at state s, i.e., the edges from the focus node v that are 1 present in the graph G from the dataset, but are not yet present in G(t).
The results in Fig. 3 show that CGVAE is excellent at matching graph statistics, while generating valid, novel and unique molecules for all datasets considered.
This allows us to generate molecules with very high QED values by performing gradient ascent in the latent space using the trained QED-scoring network.
We proposed CGVAE, a sequential generative model for graphs built from a VAE with GGNNs in the encoder and decoder.
Using masks that enforce chemical rules, we specialized our model to the application of molecule generation and achieved state-of-the-art generation and optimization results.
Future work will need to link to the chemistry community to define additional metrics that further guide the construction of models and datasets for real-world molecule design tasks.
headline: With an emphasis on applications in chemistry, we explore the task of learning to generate graphs that conform to a distribution observed in training data
